3.text: DNA sequencing is the process of working out

7.text: the order of the building blocks, or bases, in a strand of DNA.

13.text:
Before we can sequence the DNA, it has to
be cut up into smaller pieces

19.text: that are inserted into plasmid DNA

24.text: and then put into bacterial cells.

28.text:
This makes it possible to produce lots and
lots of copies of it

37.text:
The DNA is then isolated from the bacteria
and sent for sequencing.

43.text:
The isolated DNA is transferred to a plate
where the sequencing reaction will take place.

52.text: A mixture of ingredients is added.

54.text: These include free DNA bases (A, C, G, T),

68.text:
Modified DNA bases labelled with coloured,
fluorescent tags are also added.

84.text:
To start the sequencing reaction, everything
is heated to 96 degrees Celsius.

90.text: This separates the DNA into two single strands.

95.text: The temperature is then lowered to 50 degrees.

99.text:
This enables the DNA primers to bind to the
plasmid DNA.

104.text: The temperature is then increased to 60 degrees

107.text: and the enzyme DNA polymerase binds to the primer DNA.

113.text: DNA polymerase starts making a new strand of DNA

117.text: by adding unlabelled DNA bases to the target DNA.

123.text:
It continues to add DNA bases until a terminator
base is added.

129.text: These terminator bases have been chemically altered

132.text: so that no more bases can be added to the new strand of DNA.

137.text: Once a terminator base is added, the DNA polymerase enzyme

142.text: stops making DNA and falls away from the strand.

146.text: Everything is then heated to 96 degrees Celsius again

150.text: to separate the new DNA strand from the original strand.

158.text: This process of heating and cooling is repeated again and again

162.text: to produce lots of fragments of DNA of different lengths.

171.text:
The length of each fragment depends on when
a terminator base got added.

188.text:
To read the sequence of the DNA the various
fragments are separated by length

198.text:
A capillary tube is lowered into each well
of the plate and an electrical charge is applied.

204.text:
This causes the negatively-charged DNA molecules
to move through the capillary tube.

212.text: Each capillary contains a porous gel.

216.text:
The shorter fragments of DNA move through
the gel more easily than the longer DNA fragments.

225.text:
As a result, the fragments become arranged
by size, from the shortest to the longest.

233.text: As the DNA fragments come to the end of the capillary,

236.text: a laser makes the terminator bases light up.

240.text: The colour is detected by a camera and recorded.

245.text: Each terminator base is labelled with a different colour.

248.text: ‘A’ fluoresces green, ‘C’ blue, ‘G’ yellow, and ‘T’ red.

260.text:
The shortest DNA fragments will be read first,
and the longest read last.

267.text:
The sequencing machine records the colour
of the terminator bases as a series of coloured blocks.

274.text:
Each coloured block represents the labelled,
terminator base at the end of each fragment of DNA.

282.text:
By converting the colours into letters we
get the sequence of our piece of DNA.
